page.title: 14The Old School House contd.
page.content: The servants and animals would have lived in the rear of the house where the ceiling beams are of inferior quality wood and are not champered. Charring of the rafters above the centre of the main hall show that the fire used to be in the middle of that room, but later improvements positioned it at the side of the room. It seems that modernisations were carried out in Tudor times when the floor was added to the hall. The main support timbers which carry the floor show indications of a previous use. Upstairs there are Tudor doorways to the bedrooms and missing curved wind-braces must have been removed during a more recent modernisation.One fascinating feature is a candle burn on a beam beside one of the bedroom doors.
